title: How do publishers pay authors? - Quora

response.answer_text: It comes down two ways: You pitch them a book and if they smell the money and there’s a possibility of someone else taking it, they will offer an advance agains future earnings. So let’s say they offer you $10,000 advance. After everything gets signed, you, but most likely your agent, receives a check for $10,000. The agent will have it in a special account, will extract their 15% maybe 20% depending on the agent and the deal. He will then send you either a check of a money transfer. You won’t get another dime until your book sales break the $10,000 level. Then you’ll get royalty payments every quarter. Or you can get a deal for royalty only. in Which case you start earning money with the first book.

I got a $10,000 advance, $5000 on acceptance and $5000 on delivery. Since I had already written the whole thing before it was submitted, that interval was short. My agent got 15%. The advance is against sales, so until I had sold about 7000 copies, I was still in the red. That is over, and I get a royalty check twice a year. My royalties were structured as follows. 8% on the first 5000 copies, 10% on the next 5000 copies, 12% on all copies sold after that. My agent gets 15% of the royalties.
